conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on blocks A and B using static equilibrium and impending motion conditions.
Block A is placed on a horizontal ground, and block B is pushed by a horizontal force and is in close contact with block A.
The contact surface between A and B is vertical.
The coefficient of kinetic friction between A and B is μ1, and between A and the ground is μ2.
The maximum static friction force is equal to the sliding friction force.
Determine the mass ratio of A to B.
Identify the forces acting on each block.
For block B: Horizontal force F applied to B.
For block B: Normal force NBA from A on B.
For block B: Frictional force fBA from A on B, which is equal to μ1 NBA.
For block B: Gravitational force mB g.
For block B: Normal force NAB from B on A.
For block B: Frictional force fAB from A on B, which is equal to μ1 NAB.
For block A: Normal force NA from the ground.
For block A: Gravitational force mA g.
For block A: Frictional force fA from the ground, which is equal to μ2 NA.
For block A: Normal force NBA from B on A.
For block A: Frictional force fAB from B on A, which is equal to μ1 NAB.
Set up the equation for block B: The horizontal force F is balanced by the frictional force fBA, F = μ1 NBA.
Set up the equation for block B: The vertical forces are balanced, NBA = mB g.
Substitute NBA = mB g into the horizontal force equation, F = μ1 mB g.
Set up the equation for block A: The vertical forces are balanced, NA = mA g + NBA.
Set up the equation for block A: The horizontal forces are balanced, fA = fAB.
